channel.title: Cameron is an idiot, that is all
channel.description:
so we have a referendum coming up to switch voting systems, and we also got a letter from the conservative party/david cameron bashing on the alternative vote system
here are his points
"1: it's unfair because extreme parties like the bnp have their vote counted multiple times"
by extreme parties he really means every party, if a single party gets more than 50% of the votes with them as the first choice, they get elected, simple as that
and by counted multiple times, it's not like someone will vote for the bnp and the bnp will get 3 votes from them, it means someone can vote bnp and if the bnp don't do well the voter can have their vote go to another party, instead of them just voting for the other party in the first place since the bnp are shit and won't get in
"2: it doesn't work because it's not the current system"
yeah, seriously
"3: it's obscure, 3 countries in the world use it"
yeah, seriously

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:26, topic:391937”]1. Even if you allocate seats proportionally, you still need a way to count the votes.

  1. Of course there are other methods than AV or FPTP, but you need something. If we’re finding it this hard to get people to adopt AV, fucked if we’d ever get people to adopt multi member systems or anything like that.[/quote]
  2. Sainte-Laguë method (And many other) is usable way to convert votes into seats. You vote on a party/candidate, and then distribute the seats according to how many votes they got. Fair and simple.

Let say you got 80K votes, Lothy got 60K, MITB got 21K and I got 12.5K votes. We all have our own parties and we are going to distribute 8 seats. With FPTP you would get all 8 (And I and MITB would after some elections disappear.), given that voters was evenly distributed. With AV, you and Lothy will fight over some MPs. Lets take a look with PR/Modified SL-method (Used to prevent that a small party get a cheap seat)

Yellow colour means that you got a MP.

The only voters who had 100% wasted votes was mine (But if I got the 9th seat, nearly 0% of the votes would be wasted). MITB would most likely never get a seat under FPTP or AV, but got a deserved seat.
Total votes was 173500, that means 21000-22000 votes per seat.
With Leveling seats: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utjevningsmandater you even out the differences made by PR.

  1. Yes you need something, so why don’t choose something that works?
    I would think it would be easier to implement a good system, that a bad system is only somewhat better than the worst voting system (FPTP).

Of course there are other methods than AV or FPTP, but you need something. If we’re finding it this hard to get people to adopt AV, fucked if we’d ever get people to adopt multi member systems or anything like that.

@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:24, topic:391937”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=489102.msg3590807#msg3590807 date=1304624166]
Why such a stupid system though? Why don’t you throw all the votes on one big pile, and divide the seats by that outcome?
[/quote]

Because the system is designed to elect local representatives.

Also, you’d still need to perform something like FPTP or AV on that big pile, would you not? You’d be fixing the disparity in constituency sizes, but you’d still be vulnerable to minority rule.[/quote]

en.wikipedia.org

Proportional representation

Proportional representation (PR) characterizes electoral systems by which divisions into an electorate are reflected proportionately into the elected body. If n% of the electorate support a particular political party, then roughly n% of seats will be won by that party. The essence of such systems is that all votes contribute to the result: not just a plurality, or a bare majority, of them. The most prevalent forms of proportional representation all require the use of multiple-member voting The m...


en.wikipedia.org

Webster/Sainte-Laguë method

The Webster/Sainte-Laguë method, often simply Webster method or Sainte-Laguë method (French pronunciation: ​[sɛ̃t.la.ɡy]), is a highest quotient method for allocating seats in party-list proportional representation used in many voting systems. It is named in Europe after the French mathematician André Sainte-Laguë and in United States after statesman and senator Daniel Webster. The method is quite similar to the D'Hondt method, but uses different divisors. In most cases the largest remainder meth...

No FPTP or AV (Actually some sort some places, but this is only to rearrange the party list). Wasted votes are at minimum, and not at least 50% wasted votes that you get in FPTP and AV.

Wasted votes: Any votes that did not elect a MP.

I don’t know what you mean by “minority rule”, but you’re making sure that the percentage of votes is similar to the percentage of seats. And isn’t that what the outcome of an election should be?
